page.title: 17LANDSCAPE AROUND EDGEFIELD
page.content: The land around Edgefield is gently undulating, with several small copses. Fields for grazing and crops are varied in size, none so big as to create a prairie effect. There is good mixed hedging with mature trees, primarily oak and ash, and some new planting. Two areas of woodland are coniferous with borders of deciduous trees. Little Wood has been designated a site of special scientific interest because of its sessile oaks, rare in this part of the country and particularly good for charcoal. A fourth wood is an attractive walking area with hidden ponds. Three streams, tributaries of the rivers Bure and Glaven, wind through the area. Wild plants and flowers can be found in the hedgerows and woodlands which provide a good habitat for small animals and birds.
